topic.title: Default Settings in the Identity Service

section.p: The Identity service, based on OpenStack Keystone, is a vital part of , and as such it is installed automatically by the lifecycle manager (just after MySQL and RabbitMQ). Once your cloud is up and running, you can customize Keystone in a number of ways, including integrating with LDAP servers. This topic describes the default configuration. See for changes you can implement. Also see for information on integrating with an LDAP provider.

section.title: Default settings
section.p: The identity service configuration options are described in the OpenStack documentation on the identity service configuration file (for Liberty) page on the OpenStack site.
The "default" domain is automatically created during the installation to contain the various, required OpenStack service accounts including the following:

These are required accounts and are used by the underlying OpenStack services. These accounts should not be removed or reassigned to a different domain. The "default" domain should only be used for these service accounts.
For details on how to create additional users, see .

body.section:
Pre-Installed roles
The following are the pre-installed Roles. Additional roles can be created by UIDs with the 'admin' role. Roles are defined on a per service basis (more information available at: Manage projects, users, and roles on the OpenStack web site.
Role Description
admin The 'superuser' role. Provides full access to all of the HPE Helion OpenStack services across all domains and projects. This role should only be given to a cloud administrator.
_member_ A general role that enables a user to access resources within an assigned project including creating, modifying, and deleting compute, storage, and network resources.
Additional information on these roles can be found in each service policy that is stored in the /etc/PROJECT/policy.json files where PROJECT is a placeholder for an OpenStack service. For example, the Compute (Nova) service roles are stored in the /etc/nova/policy.json file. Each service policy file defines the specific API functions available to a role label.
